en: Interview with Anne May, 2020-01-11

Interview with Anne May of Arrowmont School of Arts and Crafts. May provides a background for the school before discussing the events of the fire. She recounts helping the artists in residence to evacuate from the campus before evacuating from the town herself. She then tells about the community involvement Arrowmont had in Gatlinburg during the recovery period. This is a representative quote from the interview: "There were people out there that their interest was knowing that in order for Gatlinburg to come back, people were gonna have to be very purposeful in how they contributed to that effort."
Date
Format
motion pictures (visual works)
Extent
Subject
Evacuation of civilians
Wildfires

Business owners and staff

Arrowmont School of Arts and Crafts
Description

Interview with Anne May of Arrowmont School of Arts and Crafts. May provides a background for the school before discussing the events of the fire. She recounts helping the artists in residence to evacuate from the campus before evacuating from the town herself. She then tells about the community involvement Arrowmont had in Gatlinburg during the recovery period. This is a representative quote from the interview: "There were people out there that their interest was knowing that in order for Gatlinburg to come back, people were gonna have to be very purposeful in how they contributed to that effort."

Captions in English
Bibliographic Description in MODS
Interview with Anne May, 2020-01-11
Interview Questions
Can you state your name and tell us about yourself?
Tell me about your work at Arrowmont.
Will you tell us about the Arrowmont School of Arts and Crafts?
Can you tell us about the Artist in Residence program?
What is Arrowmon't situation within Gatlinburg?
Is there any other community involvement that you would like to share?
Tell us about the weeks and days leading to the wildfires?
Leading up to the fires, were people talking about this becoming something potentially worse?
At what point did you become concerned?
When people were bringing their artwork to Arrowmont, did you hear them talking about what they had seen?
What time is it after the artists in residence were evacuated?
What did you see when evacuating?
What were you thinking on the drive home? Were you alone?
Once you got home, what were your next actions?
Once you got home, what were your next actions?
Did you know what was going on at Arrowmont?
When you left your home, where did you go?
When you get to Knoxville, what happens then?
So you were still able to call Bill (husband) through the night?
Had you been watching the news?
How did social media play a role that evening?
Did you hear from anyone that had lost their home?
When did you learn that Arrowmont had survived?
When did you learn that Arrowmont had survived?
Can you describe what it was like seeing the devastation?
When did Arrowmont bring the staff back together? What were those days like when you all came together after the fire?
Were you having conversations with the donors at the time?
Do you remember if any of the volunteers at Arrowmont had lost their homes?
What are some ways that Arrowmont supported the community after the fire?
Were there any memorable stories from that time that you would like to share?
Can you tell us about the event on Christmas at Arrowmont?
Can you tell me about the recovery efforts in Gatlinburg?
How has the wildfire impacted you emotionally?
How do you feel the fires shaped community relations?
Can you share your thoughts on the phrase "Mountain Tough" that came out of the fire?
Do you feel that this event could happen again? Is Gatlinburg prepared if that were to happen?
Was there anything else surprising or good that came out of this?
Could you tell us what the value in preserving this event is?
Is there anything else that we haven't talked about that you would like to share?
Places Mentioned
Arrowmont School of Arts and Crafts
